name: Sonrisa Family Farms Kid Mohair
description: Washed, naturally-colored Mohair fiber from kid Angora goats. This luxurious fiber is known for its warmth, beauty and durability. Kid fiber is the most ideally suited graded Mohair for fine knits like hats, mittens, sweaters, scarves or cowls. It has a very distinct sheen, and it also blends well with wool or alpaca fiber. Mohair can stretch an average of 30% of its length and spring back into shape, which makes this fiber in garments resist wrinkling, stretching or sagging during wear. These lovely naturally-colored locks, from Lisa Colorado's herd, come washed and ready to card. The small amount of vegetable matter that may be present is easily separated when working with this fiber. Sold in 4 ounce increments. Choose from 3 natural colors when ordering: silver/cream (photo 1), honey/silver (photo 2), charcoal/silver (photo 3) Shipping and handling: $8.00 via USPS Priority Mail Mohair’s Principal Properties: Mohair is similar to wool, although it does possess other unique properties not found in any other type of fiber. Luster: The luster of mohair is one of the most important characteristics. Luster is the natural sheen of the fiber caused by light being reflected more directly by the larger outer scales of the fiber. This luster or sheen helps dyed mohair resist fading caused by time and the elements and makes it very hard wearing. Non-Flammability: Mohair is almost non-flammable. When placed under, or near, a naked flame, it tends to shrivel into a bead like ash. Once taken away from the flame, burning stops instantaneously. Early children’s Teddy Bears were made from mohair because of this property and because there is less allergic reaction to mohair than wool. Durability: Mohair can be twisted or bent without damaging the fiber. This is due to its structure, supporting the claim that it is the most durable of all animal fibers. Elasticity: Mohair will stretch an average 30% over its length and then will be able to spring back into shape. Due to this property, mohair garments resist wrinkling, stretching or sagging during wear. Moisture Relation: All natural fibers from animals have the ability to absorb and release atmospheric moisture. They breathe where man made fibers do not. Resistance to Soiling: This property commends its use for woven fabrics, due to the factor that dust does not come to rest on slippery fibers. Shaking and brushing can easily remove any dust remaining on woven fabrics. Dye Ability: Mohair dyes easily and brilliantly. Tensile Strength: Mohair possesses great strength. Diameter to diameter, it is stronger than steel.

name: Felted Alpaca Jacket
description: This luxurious, custom designed and tailored jacket is made from hand-felted Alpaca fiber. An entire Alpaca fleece is carded and felted by Katherine Jolda, then turned over to Mali Mrozinski for the design and construction of the piece. In photos two and three you can see an example of a recently ordered custom coat that was designed with input from the client, with a focus on shaping and accentuation of the waist line. Please allow up to 3 months from the time of ordering for all design and construction. This jacket can be made from a distance, a detailed list of measurements is provided and consultations via skype and email is required through the design process. If you do live in the area, several meetings for custom fitting and design discussion are necessary. Both Mali and Katharine live in Oakland. Contact the Fibershed Marketplace to create a payment installment plan (2 or 3 payment options) for your new coat! fibershed@gmail.com Shipping and handling: Domestic and International shipping varies upon location.

Martha has Wensleydale sheep that have long shiny curls. Marlie preserved the curls while hand spinning them. Other fleeces are slightly less curly (they are a cross breed with cormo, so softer) and these were spun as a single bulky yarn. The sweater is hand knit by Marlie, using her Bo-Rage hand spun yarns. Also available as a knit kit. Shipping via insured mail: $14.95

description: The Mitt Kit includes two patterns to choose from and two beautiful Bo-Rage handspun yarns to make your own whimsical and cozy fingerless gloves. Designed by Marlie de Swart, who hand spun the yarn from local wool that is hand-washed and combed. The wool is from Martha Cant's ranch, Starbuck Station, and Mimi Luebberman's Windrush Farm. Martha Cant raises a luster filled and very soft Wenslydale and Cormo flock, Mimi raises a mix of high quality Corriedale and Shetland sheep. The kit includes: • enough yarn for one pair of gloves • 1 skein Bo-Rage hand spun wensleydale curls from Starbuck Farm • 1 skein Bo-Rage hand spun corriedale/finn single, bulky from Windrush Farm • Pattern for 2 different pairs of mitts Skill level: beginner Shipping and handling: $8.00

name: Hand Spun Bo-Rage Wensleydale Curls
description: Natural colored bulky, single spun by Marlie de Swart to retain the curls. Available in white (shown) or grey. The Wool comes from Starbuck Farm in Valley Ford, West Sonoma County, where rancher Martha Cant is a well known spinner and shepherd who tends her flock by covering them year around to ensure the best fleeces for hand spinners. The Wensleydale and Cormo mix guarantees a long staple lock and curl, and a silky softness. These fleeces are hand scoured and washed, then the locks are individually teased from the fleece and aligned for easier spinning. They are spun so the curls stay intact. Starbuck Farm is approximately 30 miles from the home of hand spinner Marlie de Swart, who does all the processing: scouring, washing, teasing and finally spinning. Each skein is approximately 5oz. and 70 yds. Shipping and handling: $3 for the first skein and $2 for each additional skein

name: Sleeveless Shirt Pattern
description: Sleeveless knit top by Kacy Dapp sports a scoop neck in the front and back and a curled hemline. Stripes can be added as shown in the photograph or at random up the body. There are three sizing options to create this shirt: Block or allow the top to drape on the body with wear. Decrease or add rounds, as time alters the top. Give it to someone you adore if it doesn’t fit. Recommended yarn: Foxfibre® Boiled Cotton Chenille Yarn, about 650-680 yards. Visit www.vreseis.com/yarn.html to purchase yarn. If stripes are desired, one third of the yarn requirements should be in a contrasting color. If stripes are not desired, ignore color notations throughout the pattern. Needles: (2) sets of 36" circular needle in size US 10 (6.0mm), (1) set of double-pointed needles in size US 10 (6.0mm) Gauge: 2¾ stitches per inch Pattern will be emailed to you within 24 hours of purchase.

artists.name: Kacy Dapp / hand knit goods and patterns

name: Coreopsis tinctoria seeds
description: Certified Organic Coreopsis seed from the Lagunitas watershed of western Marin County was harvested in the late summer and early fall of 2011. This hand-harvested seed has been lovingly packaged and is ready for your personal, community, or local school dye garden! We've found the coreopsis flowers to be the strongest, most permanent, and easy to grow sources of deep orange color available. The 2011 crop was predominantly used to create our well loved "Syd the Squid" dye kit. We let just enough of the flowers mature, so we can offer a limited supply of seed for your 2012 growing season! Sow indoors 4-6 weeks before the last frost date and plant your starts outdoors when all frost potential is gone. In most regions coreopsis is an annual, but near the ocean and in very temperate climates, it has a perennial growth pattern and will dye back in winter, but re-sprout in the spring. Grows 24"-60" high depending on soil fertility. Shipping and handling: $1.50 via USPS first class mail.

artists.name: Monica Paz Soldan / hand knits and dye plants

name: Natural Dye Plant CSA
description: CSA Memberships for 2014 will be on sale in the spring. Nature's Cauldron Farm, located in Camptonville in the Sierra Nevada foothills of Northern California, is possibly the only natural dye plant CSA (Community Supported Agriculture) in the US, and began in 2011. Share holders will become part of Birdsong Sundstrom's small farm’s mission to help heal the planet through production and use of natural dye plants in a regional manner, both for clothing production and for artistic expression. Share holders will receive four shipments over the harvest season (August 2013 through February 2014) from some or all of the following plants (depending upon growing season): Black-eyed Susan, marigold, zinnia, rhubarb, dahlia, dyer's coreopsis, cosmos, Japanese indigo, bronze fennel, comfrey, madder, lady’s bedstraw, yarrow, osage orange, elder, oak galls and acorns, lodgepole pine bark, eucalyptus, black walnut, Oregon grape, hollyhock, tansy, and various lichens. Instructions for mordanting and dyeing will be included with each shipment, as well as project suggestions for using your newly colored yarns.

name: Crochet-felt wool potholders
description: Handcrafted wool potholders, designed by Molly de Vries of Ambatalia in Sausalito, and crocheted and felted by Tisha Thompson of Mill Valley. Made of wool from Woolly Egg Ranch in Mill Valley, in a combination of natural gray wool and wool that has been indigo-dyed by Rebecca Burgess with locally grown indigo. Every piece made to order. We will ship 5 to 7 days after receiving your order. Available in two shapes: rectangular, approximately 8" x 12" round, approximately 9" diameter Wash in cold water and lay flat to dry. Shipping and handling: $4.95 for one potholder, and $2 for additional potholders.

artists.name: Molly de Vries / Ambatalia hand-crafted textiles

name: Raw Karakul Wool
description: Raw wool is unwashed, straight from the sheep. It will need to be washed (with no agitation) with very hot water, some type of soap, rinsed, and air dried. It will then be ready for carding or combing, in preparation for spinning or for use in other craft projects. This wool is from "Jennifer", a Karakul ewe who lives at Fleece of Abali (fleeceofabali.com, email: hamkath40.yahoo.com) in Vacaville, CA. Her wool is cream in color, once washed. Karakul sheep are a very ancient breed originating in Central Asia and their wool is coarse - suitable for rugs and can even be used for warp, if spun correctly. (For more information, see "The Fleece & Fiber Sourcebook, b Deborah Robson & Carol Ekarius). This wool is offered by Jacalyn Post at $6/6 oz. Currently, 48 oz are available. Shipping and handling: $5.60 for the first 6 oz, plus $1.00 for each additional 6 oz., via USPS first class mail.

name: Knit-Felt Tote Bag
description: This tote is the creation of Jacalyn Post. Made from Jacob Sheep wool from sheep who live in Solano County, the tote is knitted and then felted. The i-cord knit-felt handles are hand stitched onto the bag after felting. The tote is approximately 16 inches wide at the top and is approximately 6 inches deep - large enough to hold that knitting project you are taking with you! Since Jacob sheep vary in their color pattern, your tote's color pattern may vary slightly from the photos. In photo #2, the tote is the center bag. To make the tote even easier to use, Jacalyn has sewn a piece of Karakul Sheep wool felt into the bottom of the bag to provide additional stability. Please allow 2-3 weeks for your tote to be made for you.

name: Hand-braided wool lead rope
description: Beautiful hand-braided lead ropes, made of hand spun Navajo-Churro wool sourced from Debby Bradford's sheep in Hopland, in natural charcoal gray and white. Spun and braided by Jacalyn Post, who calls her company "Jack's Wool/Isabelle's Items" after her parents, both craftspeople who taught her to value working with her hands. The lead is braided using a Kumihimo influenced technique, with a swivel clip on one end and a firm knot on the other end. Jacalyn has reinforced the clip end by wrapping it near the clip with matching yarn and inserting extra yarn through the clip swivel and then weaving that in. Lead rope or show lead - not intended for tethering. Choose from 3 different braiding designs: Barber Pole, Spots, or Twill (see photo #3 at left) Length: varies between 4' and 4'6" Shipping and handling: $4.95

name: Knit-felt Hot Pads
description: Bring the beauty of our fibershed into your kitchen with these hand made hot pads by Jacalyn Post, who calls her company "Jack's Wool & Isabelle's Items" after her parents, both craftspeople who taught her to value working with her hands. Jacalyn spins the wool from her own flock in Solano County, or uses wool from other parts of the fibershed. Then she knits the handspun yarn and fulls it, sometimes adding a needle felted accent. Lastly, a crochet loop is added. Wool sources include: Jacob, Karakul, California Red, Navajo-Churro, Shetland, Wensleydale, CVM (California Variegated Mutant), llama, and alpaca. Options: 1. Karakul wool with needle felt flower. The hand spun yarn was dyed with Scottish Broom from Contra Costa County (photo #1, top left). Approx. 6 inches x 6.5 inches. 2. Karakul wool striped with natural grey and white and yarn dyed with Scottish Broom (photo #1, top right). Approx. 5.75 inches x 6.5 inches. 3. Dark grey solid CVM with yellow iron bark flower (photo #1, bottom left). Approx. 6.5 inches x 7 inches. 4. Grey Navajo-Churro from a ram named "Satchmo". Alternating subtle dark and light grey stripes (photo #1, bottom right). Approx. 6.5 inches square. 5. Jacob Sheep wool dyed with red iron bark (Eucalyptus). Very warm colors! (photo #3, upper left). Approx. 7 inches square. 6. Cream colored Karakul wool from a very special wether named "Quentin". A Scottish Broom needle felted flower in the center is a nice contrast with Quentin's beautiful wool. Very thick. Approx. 6.5 inches by 7 inches. (photo #3, upper right). 7. Oatmeal solid (California Red) – the wool was sourced from Patsy Galati’s sheep in San Ramon. This is a coarser yarn with lots of character from this sheep’s wool. The color comes from the dark red hairs of the Barbados sheep, which was bred with the Tunis sheep to create this breed. A needle felted paw print adds a pet theme for the animal lover! Approx. 6.5 inches x 7 inches. (photo #3, bottom left) 8. Natural Jacob wool, sourced from Robin Lynde's Jacob Sheep in Vacaville. Striped natural white and dark brown. Approx. 6.5 inches by 7.5 inches. (photo #3, lower right). Shipping and handling: $3.00 for the first hot pad, plus $1.00 for each additional one, via USPS first class mail.

name: Knit-felt Mug Rugs
description: What are "mug rugs"? We used to call them "coasters" but "mug rugs" is a better description of the purpose of these handy and decorative items. These little mug rugs will protect your table tops while bringing the beauty of our fibershed into your home or office. They are large enough for your favorite mugs. Whether enjoying a mug of coffee, hot chocolate or tea, you will appreciate having a large, sturdy mug rug on which to rest your beverage. Hand made by Jacalyn Post, who calls her company "Jack's Wool/Isabelle's Items" after her parents, both craftspeople who taught her to value working with her hands. Jacalyn spins the wool from her own flock in Solano County, or uses wool from other parts of the fibershed. Then she knits the handspun yarn and fulls it, sometimes adding a needle felted accent. Wool sources include: Jacob, Karakul, California Red, Navajo-Churro, Shetland, Wensleydale, CVM (California Variegated Mutant), llama, and alpaca. one-of-a-kind design and color options: 1. Grey made from hand spun California Variegated Mutant (CVM) Sheep Wool from Colleen Simon's flock in Solano County. Size: approximately 5.5 inches wide and 5 inches high. See photo #2, left. 2. Multi hand spun Jacob Sheep Wool embellished with a sunflower, needle felted with wool naturally dyed with red iron bark (eucalyptus). Size: approximately 5.25 inches square. See photo #2, center. 3. Jacob Sheep wool, hand spun multi on bottom 2/3 and hand spun dark brown top stripe. Size: approximately 5.5 inches square. See photo #2, right. 4. Hand spun Karakul Sheep Wool from Fleece of Abali flock in Solano County. Grey and white wool has been dyed with Scottish broom. An accent stripe of naturally white Karakul wool has been added. Size: approximately 5 inches wide and 4.5 inches high. See photo #3, left. 5. Hand spun grey Karakul Sheep wool from the Fleece of Abali flock in Solano County. The natural grey of the Karakul is bordered by a top and bottom stripe of Karakul wool naturally dyed with Scottish broom. Size: approximately 5.25 inches wide and 5 inches high. See photo #3, center. 6. Hand spun naturally grey Karakul Sheep wool from the Fleece of Abali flock in Solano County. Wool dyed with Scottish broom to produce a beautiful green is added in an accent stripe. Size: approximately 5.5 inches wide and 4.75 inches high. See photo #3, right. 7. Hand spun Jacob Sheep wool has been dyed with red iron bark (Eucalyptus) to achieve a deep red base and top stripe of gold and red. Size: approximately 6 inches wide and 5.75 inches high. See photo #4, left. 8. Karakul Sheep wool from the Fleece of Abali flock in Solano County has been dyed with Scottish broom. Using one strand of the dyed wool and one strand of natural Karakul white, Jacalyn has created a mottled mug rug, accented with a sunflower needle felted with wool dyed with red iron bark (Eucalyptus). Size: approximately 5.25 inches wide and 5 inches high. See photo #4, right. Shipping and handling: $3.00 for the first mug rug, plus $1.00 for each additional one, via USPS first class mail.

options.name: 3. Multi Jacob with brown top stripe
4. Green dyed Karakul with white stripe
8. Dark brown with light grey top stripe

name: Knit-Felt Large Hot Pads
description: Like the smaller version, these hot pads are an excellent way to protect your table from hot dishes - or just add a decorative touch to any setting. Made from hand spun wool and then fulled and blocked, these hot pads measure approximately 11" x 9" in the California Variegated Wool (CVM) option and 10' x 10" in the Jacob option. They are washable in hot or cold water. Then, roll and wring out by hand (do not use spin cycle) and lay flat to dry. THESE COLORS ARE CURRENTLY SOLD OUT. NEW BREEDS AND COLORS ARE IIN THE WORKS. PLEASE CHECK BACK! Made by Jacalyn Post who calls her company "Jack's Wool & Isabelle's Items after her parents, both craftspeople who taught her to value working with her hands. Jacalyn spins the wool from her own flock in Solano County or uses wool from other parts of the fibershed. Fiber sources include: Jacob, Karakul, California Red, Navajo-Churro, Shetland, Wensleydale, CVM (California Variegated Mutant), llama and alpaca. Options: 1. grey Jacob Sheep Wool with rust stripes of Jacob naturally dyed with red iron bark (eucalyptus) (top hot pad in photo #1) 2. grey Jacob Sheep Wool with green stripes of Jacob naturally dyed with Scottish broom (bottom hot pad in photo #1) 3. Warm brown CVM with stripes of cream CVM (middle hot pad in photo #1)

name: Knit-felt Bowl
description: Sweet storage vessels for you or your pets — hand made bowls by Jacalyn Post, who calls her company "Jack's Wool/Isabelle's Items" after her parents, both craftspeople who taught her to value working with her hands. These unique handmade bowls have many uses — storing cat or dog treats, holding change or jewelry, or just as a decorative object. Jacalyn spins the wool from her own flock in Solano County, or uses wool from other parts of the fibershed. She knits the handspun yarn and fulls it, then lines each bowl with felt from Robin Lynde's Jacob sheep. The needle felted paw prints are the finishing touch. Wool sources include: Jacob, Karakul, California Red, Navajo-Churro, Shetland, Wensleydale, CVM (California Variegated Mutant), llama, and alpaca. Dimensions: Approximately 2.75 inches high, 13-inch circumference, and a top opening of about 2.5 inches Color options: 1. Light with dark paw print (see photos #2 and #4 at left) 2. Dark with light paw print (see photos #1, #2 and #3 at left) 3. Pink (Jacob wool). Dyed with madder root sourced from the yard of a friend in Solano County. Wool sourced from Robin Lynde’s sheep in Vacaville. (see photo #5 at left) Shipping and handling: $4.95 for the first bowl, plus $3.00 for each additional one, via USPS first class mail.

name: Knit-felt Catnip Mouse
description: A playful treat for your feline friends — hand made mice by Jacalyn Post, who calls her company "Jack's Wool/Isabelle's Items" after her parents, both craftspeople who taught her to value working with her hands. Jacalyn spins the wool from her own flock in Solano County, or uses wool from other parts of the fibershed. She knits the handspun yarn and fulls it, then adds the needle felted features and the braided tails. Wool sources include: Jacob, Karakul, California Red, Navajo-Churro, Shetland, Wensleydale, CVM (California Variegated Mutant), llama, and alpaca. Each mouse contains organically grown catnip from Sebastopol. Color options: 1. Cream 2. Multi-color 3. Dark grey (Jacob). Wool sourced from Robin Lynde’s sheep in Vacaville. 4. Dark brown (Jacob). Wool sourced from Robin Lynde’s sheep in Vacaville. 5. Light grey (Jacob). Wool sourced from Robin Lynde’s sheep in Vacaville. 6. Red brown (CVM). Wool sourced from Colleen Simon’s sheep in Vacaville. Shipping and handling: $3.00 for the first mouse, plus $1.00 for each additional one, via USPS first class mail.

name: Knit-Felt Purses
description: These purses are the creations of Jacalyn Post. Made from either Jacob Sheep wool or CVM (California Variegated Mutant) Sheep wool, these purses are knitted and then felted. The i-cord knit-felt handles are hand stitched onto the bags after felting. The purses are embellished with a Jacob Sheep horn button for the closure. The Jacob purse is approximately 12 inches wide at the top and approximately 8 inches deep. The CVM purse is approximately 11 inches wide at the top and approximately 7 1/2 inches deep. Since sheep vary in their color pattern, your tote's color pattern may vary slightly from the photos. Please allow 2-3 weeks for each bag to be made for you. Options: 1. Jacob purse (top left in photo #1 and in photo #2) 2. CVM purse (bottom right in photo #1 and in photo #3)

name: Hand Spun Angora Yarn
description: Gorgeous two-ply angora yarn, hand-spun from Allison Arnold small flock of French and German rabbits. Make an amazingly soft "baby's first gift" or a luscious neck cowl for you! The rabbits are shorn once their fiber reaches an ideal length. The fiber is so smooth and clean, it can be instantly spun on Allison's beautiful heirloom wheel. The yarn is spun directly from the raw wool, without being processed into roving first. It is never dyed or treated in any way. The skeins are spun to showcase the nature of the angora wool. Each skein has a unique character and will "bloom" (get the classic fuzzy angora look) as you work with it. Every skein is 100 percent angora, worsted weight, with a recommended needle size of US 8. These skeins are rare, and once they sell out, it takes some time to build up stock again. We recommend purchasing what you need for your project at one time. Currently available: 1.9 oz skein - white - 56 yards (see photo 3 for color) 2.4 oz skein - white - 78 yards (see photo 3 for color) 2.7 oz skein - white - 78 yards (see photo 3 for color) 2.9 oz skein - chestnut gray - 85 yards (see photo 1, top, for color) Shipping and handling: $4.95 via USPS Priority Mail

name: Angora Rabbit Pelt
description: Lovely, soft, white angora pelt, approximately 20"x14" with a wool length of 2 inches. From a rabbit raised with love by Allison Arnold of Homestead Farms. The pelt was cured on the farm and then tanned in Ceres, California to best preserve the angora wool quality. These pelts make great gifts for people expecting a child, as they are perfect as a soft bedding for newborns. Shipping and handling: $4.95 via USPS Priority Mail.

name: Marin Blanket
description:
Direct from a small Northern California county... the Marin Blanket is a testament to what a community can create.  

Each blanket is numbered, and one of a kind.  All raw wool from the blanket came from the sheep of Mill Valley homesteader, Kenny Kirkland, and was salvaged from the barn rafters.  Marin produces 20,000 pounds of wool annually that is underutilized or thrown away.  Saving and processing Kenny's wool was a first step in putting this gorgeous, and once underutilized natural fiber to use.  Each blanket sold creates more incentive to put our local wool to use and support our local farmers!

The yarn was milled at our most local mill, the Yolo Wool Mill, and was then woven by Susan Hayes's Point Reyes Weaving Studio.  Hayes is a staple figure in West Marin's textile community, and has been a successful production weaver for decades.

The blanket is woven in an undulating twill pattern, and the dimensions (36" x 70") make it a perfect personal size throw.  

If you are part of the growing personal health movement to rid your life of synthetic fibers and colors, we recommend this blanket as your new beach towel.  This is a way to put your blanket to use! The sand just shakes right out, the wool dries quickly, and is naturally anti-microbial.

name: Harvesting Color
description: Harvesting Color, by Fibershed founder Rebecca Burgess, identifies 36 plants from across North America that will yield beautiful natural dye colors. Every bioregion is represented, with maps, plant biographies, and full color photography. Read and learn how these common, native, and naturalized plants of your community can create beautiful shades on your yarns and textiles. The book is organized seasonally, and each season culminates with a beautiful knitwear pattern to represent the work of the dyer throughout the year. With gorgeous photography by Paige Green, Harvesting Color is an essential guide for all crafters, DIYers, ecologists, botanists, artists, and gardeners. Books are signed by the author unless you would prefer them unsigned. Please choose option below when ordering. Shipping and handling: $4.95

name: Lost Coast Scarf
description: Robin Lynde’s Jacob wool give this ribbed scarf a wonderful bouncy feel, and airiness that will keep you warm for hours, whether hiking on the coast or negotiating the dark gorges of downtown. Fleece grown blacks and grays are accentuated with indigo-dyed yarn. A special scarf to keep with you all winter. Designed by Dyan Ashby, made by Monica Paz Soldan in San Francisco. Dimensions: 7” x 62” Shipping and handling: $4.95 via USPS Priority Mail.

artists.name: Monica Paz Soldan / hand knits and dye plants

name: Sinkyone Forest Scarf
description: This scarf is light and cozy and reversible. One side features short and long knit stitches and the other is over woven in a basket pattern, making it twice as warm! It comes in silver white fog and and spray flecked indigo — just like the Sinkyone forest hugging the California cliffs. The hand spun yarns are a combination of lamb's wool blended with alpaca, from Windrush Farm, creating an amazingly soft yarn that is very cuddly and insulating. Designed and hand loomed in San Francisco by Monica Paz Soldan. Size: O/S (one size fits most) Shipping and handling: $4.95 via USPS Priority Mail

artists.name: Monica Paz Soldan / hand knits and dye plants

name: Toddlers Jacket
description: A light but warm zip front hooded Jacket for baby. Mitered front panels with local indigo/oxalis dye accents. Designed and hand made by Monica Paz Soldan in San Francisco. Size: Infant or Toddler's. Specify age of child on order Shipping and handling: $4.95 via USPS Priority Mail

artists.name: Monica Paz Soldan / hand knits and dye plants

name: Fern Fingerless Gloves
description: Stylish gloves designed to keep your hands warm while allowing your fingers to be free to the do the things you need to do. Knit with Sally Fox’s organic merino raised in the Capay Valley, CA. The colors are 100% fleece grown so no dyes were used. This is a cozy merino glove with an unfussy small fern lace detail that runs the back of the hand. Designed with a fully-fashioned thumb, a refined detail not often seen in fingerless gloves. Designed by Dyan Ashby and knit by Monica Paz Soldan in San Francisco. Comes in two colors: Gingerbread and Dark Chocolate Size: O/S (one size fits most women) Length: 8” Shipping and handling: $4.95 via USPS Priority Mail.

artists.name: Monica Paz Soldan / hand knits and dye plants

name: Dillon Beach Suit Cover
description: A soft, hooded zip front vest. Perfect for our northern California beaches. Knit by Monica Paz Soldan in San Franciso, from Sue's Cormo and Hazel Flet/wool blend. Color: Cream with pokeberry fuchsia stripes and accents Size: Women's, Small 28-32" chest, Med 34-38" chest, Specify shoulder to hip length. Shipping and handling: $10.95 via USPS Priority Mail

artists.name: Monica Paz Soldan / hand knits and dye plants

name: Coastal Loop Cowl
description: Made with Sally Fox’s color-grown brown cotton and a blend of Bodega Pastures wool, this neck warmer is a combination of fun and function. The playful stripes of the raw fiber colors alternate randomly, and the combination of cotton and wool together produces a very comfortable piece for our Northern California climate, and is suitable year round. Designed by Dyan Ashby and knit in San Francisco by Monica Paz Soldan. Offered in 2 lengths: single and double. Dyan’s favorite is the double loop length for its flexibility and how the stripes inter mingle when wrapped twice. Try the single loop if you prefer a shorter length option. Either way, it’s worn for comfort and is stylish without much effort. Single: 9” x 29” Double: 9” x 56” Shipping and handling: $4.95 via USPS Priority Mail.

artists.name: Monica Paz Soldan / hand knits and dye plants

name: Fox Cotton Lace Scarf
description: Sally Fox’s color grown green organic cotton blended with organic Pima give this lovely piece its subtle green shade. This scarf is made to become a treasured heirloom. Designed and hand loomed by Monica Paz Soldan in San Francisco. Shipping and handling: $4.95 via USPS Priority Mail.

artists.name: Monica Paz Soldan / hand knits and dye plants

name: Canyon Creek Falls Scarf
description: Traditional aran cables reinterpreted give this scarf a classic yet modern feeling. A generously sized scarf knit with Robin Lynde’s Jacob sheep wool from Meridian Jacobs Farm in Vacaville, and milled at our local mill in Yolo. Jacob sheep are unique for their spotted fleeces, which are hand sorted after sheering to create the wonderful range of raw colors of the Jacob wool yarns. We’ve chosen a subtle two-tone grey combination that creates a speckled effect that undulates with the cables. Designed by Dyan Ashby. Knit by Monica Paz Soldan in San Francisco. Dimensions: 6” x 78” Color: Mushroom Shipping and handling: $4.95 via USPS Priority Mail.

artists.name: Monica Paz Soldan / hand knits and dye plants

name: Asymmetrical Collared Cowl
description: Inspired by the neckerchiefs worn by ranch hands in the designer's youth, this cowl is made with a sumptuous blend of lambswool and mohair from Windrush Farm. Unbelievably soft, this cowl will keep you very cozy. The art yarn was hand spun and dyed in walnut and oak. The thick and thin spinning technique gives the fabric a natural lacy effect. Designed and hand knit in San Francisco by Monica Paz Soldan. Shipping and handling: $4.95 via USPS Priority Mail.

artists.name: Monica Paz Soldan / hand knits and dye plants

name: Homestead Farms angora wool
description:
Beautiful angora fiber from Allison Arnold of Homestead Farms in the rolling hills of West Marin, California. Sold at $10 per ounce. Currently available:
  • White wool
  • Chestnut Agouti Grey wool (center of photo 1 at left), from Big Boy (photo 2 at left)
Please make a color selection when ordering. Wool textures and color tones vary between rabbits. They are all beautiful individuals who produce very soft and warm wool. Click here to visit the farm website. Shipping and handling: $4 for the first ounce, $2 for each additional ounce. Sent via USPS Priority Mail.

name: Organic Cotton Boucle Shirt knit kit
description: Designed by Monica Paz Soldan, this is an elegant classic summer shirt. Its seamless structure will delight as well as flatter you. If you have ever had reservations about knitting in cotton, the yarn used in this pattern is the yarn to start with. Foxfibre® Cotton Boucle yarn has plenty of bounce and will slip onto your needles with ease. If you are not a knitter and would like this piece constructed for you, we can team you up with a local knitter quite easily. Email us at fibershed@gmail.com for this option. This was the first handknit piece made for the Fibershed wardrobe. The shirt was worn on the farm, out on the town, and everywhere in between. It is an exquisite and functional garment. It was originally knit without the indigo dyed strip at the base. The blue addition (optional in the pattern) came later to highlight the collaborative work we took part in to plant the indigo fields, and to show what color-grown cotton and indigo can do when brought together. The kit includes either brown or green boucle yarn only, if you'd like to dye your own indigo strip, we have indigo seeds available on our site! The knit kit includes: 850 yards of Foxfibre® Cotton Boucle yarn. Please make a color choice when ordering. (Brown yarn shown in photos at left. Photos of the green yarn coming soon.) Pattern size: Chest 31 (36, 40) You will be emailed a printable pdf of the sweater pattern within 24 hours of purchase. Shipping and handling: $10.95 via USPS Priority Mail.

The blue addition (optional in the pattern) came later to highlight the collaborative work we took part in to plant the indigo fields, and to show what color grown cotton and indigo can do when brought together. name: Spring Sweater knitting pattern
description: This sweater was designed by Allison Reilly for the one-year Fibershed wardrobe. The original was knit with Jean Near's Utopia Ranch Merino. Reilly's innovative design was created to meet the goal of making a light weight outer layer that protected the body, and could be worn year round. The design specifically functions to keep the body temperature of the wearer from becoming too warm. Reilly also utilized as little wool yarn as possible to construct this contemporary design that resonates both aesthetically and ecologically for anyone who wears it. You will be emailed a printable pdf of the sweater pattern within 24 hours of purchase.

name: Black and White Felted Amulet
description: Made by designer Ashley Eva Brock with local alpaca and sheep wool, and metal components of patinaed brass. This necklace stands alone visually as a beautiful necklace, representing a transition from dark to light, fear to trust, insecurity to confidence, but has other purposes as well. It is infused with flower essences of Sweet Chestnut for the black and grey beads and Larch for the grey and white beads. It rests on the chest where anxiety often dwells and when its powers are needed, you simply press the amulet to your chest and breathe. Please allow 1 to 2 weeks from the time you place your order for your amulet to be made for you. Shipping and handling: $6 via USPS Priority Mail; or $3 when purchased with additional items.

name: Multi-Colored Felted Amulet
description: Made by designer Ashley Eva Brock with local alpaca and sheep wool that she has naturally dyed with indigo, madder and distaff. Metal components are patinaed brass. This necklace stands alone visually as a beautiful necklace, representing a transition from darkness to light and displaying the three primary colors, but has other purposes as well. Each of the felted beads are infused with flower essences, different ones according to color. Flower essences are different than essential oils and don’t have a scent. They instead capture the energetic healing properties of particular plants and allow the user to access strengths within them that might be hiding at the time. This amulet acts as a balancing element when worn. In addition, individual elements can be drawn upon by pressing the individual beads. The different colors assist in the following ways: -Black: for when you’re afraid of the dark or the unknown. Eases fears. -Grey: for when you’re being indecisive. Helps you access your intuition. -White: for when you’re feeling overwhelmed. Brings about clarity, flushes out negativity. -Blue: for when you’re feeling anxious and your wheels are spinning too fast. Brings about a sense of peace and tranquility. -Yellow: for when you’re feeling sad. Shines a gentle light of happiness. -Red: for when you’re feeling lethargic. Gives you a boost of energy. Please allow 1 to 2 weeks from the time you place your order for your amulet to be made for you. Shipping and handling: $6 via USPS Priority Mail; or $3 when purchased with other items.

name: Alpaca Sweater knitting pattern

Back page of pattern has customizing tips. You will be emailed a printable pdf of the sweater pattern within 24 hours of purchase.

name: Japanese Indigo seeds / San Francisco grown
description: These seeds are from the fall 2012 indigo harvest. Fresh indigo seeds have the best germination rate, so if you are not planting until 2014, you may want to wait for our 2013 harvest. Japanese indigo (Polygonum tinctorium) has been used for centuries to create a rich blue dye. The plant is easy to grow as an annual, and the leaves may be harvested 2 or 3 times during the growing season for a fresh dye vat. Each packet contains approximately 100 seeds, with planting instructions. These seeds were harvested from plants grown the backyard dye garden of Monica Paz Soldan, in San Francisco, California. Cool coastal summers, heavy fog, and summer temperatures ranging from 60-80 degrees are typical of this Sunset climate zone 17. shipping and handling: $1.50

description: Long or short sleeved knit shirt or sweater with shaped v-neck and curled ends. This piece is great a base layer or a sweater in its own right. name: Felted Tote Bag
description: Designed and created by Katharine Jolda, from a full pound of Fibershed wool felt, this seamless tote bag will become your constant carry-all. It is made from sturdy Churro or Romney wool from Bodega Pastures. The bag provides padding for your laptop and insulation for your farmers’ market haul, with a felt pocket embedded inside. It is made with traditional wet-felting techniques, whereby the loose wool fibers are made directly into the final shape. Tote is embellished with braided leather straps that wrap around the bottom to prevent stretching and are stitched with hand-made leather. Approximate dimensions: 10”x14”x 4½ ”. Current color options: White (photo 2), gray (photo 3), or brown (photo 4, shows raw wool). Colors are approximate, no two totes are exactly alike. Please allow up to two weeks for the creation of your tote bag. Shipping and handling: $15 via USPS Priority Mail.

The wool is worked with traditional wet-felting techniques, whereby the loose wool is made directly into the finished item, and fastened with a button cut from your choice of a naturally shed deer antler or a black walnut shell. A braided leather strap provides the finishing touch, and allows this purse to fit securely under your arm. Please allow up to two weeks for the creation of your purse. All yarns are available in 50 gram balls / approx. 140 yards per ball "Twirling Clouds" is a clean white blend of Romney-influenced wool and Mohair. (top in photo 1 at left) "Twirling Reddy Kilowatt" is from the wool of Reddy, a California Red ewe whose fleece is creamy white with a red influence. She, together with her Red ewe and lamb friends, made this blend of 100% wool. (middle in photo 1 at left) "Twirling Moona" is from Moona, a CVM x Merino cross ewe. She got together with her CVM friends to make this naturally creamy 100% wool yarn. (bottom in photo 1 at left) A sample packet of all the Twirl natural colored yarns is also available. Shipping and handling: $5 for the first skein of any of Mary's yarns, $1 for each additional skein. Via USPS Priority Mail.

name: Jacob lambskins
description: Step into luxury by putting a lambskin from Robin Lynde of Meridian Jacobs on the floor next to your bed. Snuggle into a lambskin on the back of the couch. Try a lambskin on your weaving bench, piano bench, folding chair or under your desk in the winter. A lambskin on your car seat will keep you warm in the winter and cooler in the summer and avoid that 'shocking' experience (static electricity) you may have when sliding out of a car seat. A lambskin makes a great gift for a new mom — luxury for her on her rocking chair or comfort for baby under the crib sheet. Elderly friends or family members will also relish the warmth and softness of a lambskin in a favorite chair or on the couch. (Some of Robin's customers swear that Jacob lambskins have medicinal qualities!) Each lambskin is unique in its pattern, but all are equally soft and beautiful. Meridian Jacobs lambskins are washable. Washing instructions: 1. If very dirty, first rinse off with cool water. 2. Fill washing machine and add Unicorn Fibre Wash or your favorite wool detergent. Put lambskin in washer and swish by hand or agitate gently for up to 3 minutes. Spin out water. 3. To rinse, repeat Step 2 without the detergent. 4. Air dry and use dryer (no heat) to fluff. Choose from 2 size ranges: size 1: Approximately 30-35" x 20-24" = $100 size 2: Approximately 38-42" x 25-29" = $136 Shipping and handling: $15.95 via USPS Priority Mail We expect more lambskins by December.

description: Robin Lynde raises natural colored Jacob sheep at her farm, Meridian Jacobs, in Solano County. Jacob wool is soft and lofty, grading in the medium to fine range. name: Jacob Horn Buttons
description: Meridian Jacob's buttons are hand made on the farm from the horns of the Jacob sheep. Each horn has a unique shape and color. Even a horn that is black on the outside may have a striking pattern when sliced into buttons," says Robin Lynde of Meridian Jacobs Farm. Buttons are sold in sets or singles. Use single buttons for purse closures or embellishment on just about anything. artists.name: Robin Lynde / Meridian Jacobs Wool and Yarns

name: Jacob roving-dark gray
description: Robin Lynde of Meridian Jacobs Farm raises Jacob sheep that are selected for their fleece and Jacob breed characteristics. She takes pride in her farm's reputation for producing top quality wool. When you mix black and white wool you get gray. When you mix Jacob fleeces you get oh-so-lovely a roving with distinct shades of gray throughout. This roving is mostly darker fibers and will spin into a dark yarn with light highlights. It is somewhat coarser than the mixed roving that is sold out. It will spin into yarn good for outer wear, bags, etc. Sold in 8 ounce lots. Shipping and handling: $11.35 via USPS Priority Mail.

name: Jacob V-Shawl
description: The v-shawl is a wonderful design that stays put when worn. The warp colors cross in the back to create unique designs. The front pieces are 14.5" wide and 33" from the lower front to the v-shape at the neck. It has 4" twisted fringe. Shawl 808-B is shown on the left in Photo 1 and in Photos 2 and 3. The front pieces are 15" wide and 33" from the lower front to the v-shape at the neck. It has 5" twisted fringe.

description: Robin Lynde of Meridian Jacobs wove a series of blankets using wool yarn spun from her neighbor's Corriedale-cross sheep. Each blanket is woven with a different weft yarn and/or pattern. artists.name: Robin Lynde / Meridian Jacobs Wool and Yarns

name: Handwoven & Handspun Jacob Wool Throw
description: Robin Lynde of Meridian Jacobs Farm creates these beautiful wool throws. They are handwoven using the handspun natural colored wool from her flock of Jacob sheep. Handspinning is the best way to create yarn of random colors, and all the shades of white, gray, and black are represented in these blankets. In addition the handspun yarn is bouncy and full of life, giving these blankets a terrific drape. Fox's cotton is rich in tannins and antioxidants, and is felt to be a modern day medicinal fiber for those that know and love it! Each skein is approximately 3.5 oz. / 220 yards Approximately 1000 yards per pound *This cotton was not processed in the region, but every purchase of moves us a step closer to our vision to manufacture yarns on the farm! artists.name: Sally Fox / Vreseis Ltd. color-grown cotton

name: Knit-felt Vest
description: When wearing this beautiful garment, you will be warmed with not only the soft textures, but also with the amazing care that designer Sierra Reading put into the process of creating this wearable form of art. First hand-knitted with Cormo Wool roving, the knitted yardage is then wrapped around a sturdy pipe, and wrapped in a sturdy, reusable, plastic bag and felted by being dragged behind a bicycle (an invention created by the artist). The felted textile is then cut into the pieces to form the vest, and each piece is dyed in yellow onion skins and mordanted in iron. After laying in the sun to dry, pieces are hand-sewn together to form the beautiful vest that you see now. Each vest made is a one-of-a-kind wearable work of art. When ordering a vest, please allow two to three months for the process to be completed. If you would like to order the garment in a different color, you may choose the alternate color option below, and the artist will contact you for a discussion of color possibilities. Shipping and handling: $14.95 via USPS Priority Mail.
